content.statement: aku:math:category-theory:category-laws is a fundamental concept in Formal-Sciences Mathematics Pure-Mathematics Category-Theory that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku:math:category-theory:category-laws helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku:math:category-theory:category-laws include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.

associativity.latex: \text{For } f: A \to B, g: B \to C, h: C \to D: \quad h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f
associativity.description: Composition is associative - parentheses don't matter

left_identity.description: Composing with identity on the right gives the original morphism

right_identity.description: Composing with identity on the left gives the original morphism

implications: We can chain morphisms without ambiguity
Categories form an algebraic structure similar to monoids

verification_examples.associativity: Function composition is associative: h(g(f(x))) can be computed in any grouping

verification_examples.haskell:
-- Associativity
(h . g) . f = h . (g . f)
-- Identity
f . id = f
id . f = f

applications.context: Category theory provides the theoretical foundation for functional programming, including composition, functors, and monads
Type theory uses categorical semantics, especially cartesian closed categories
